item.title: Horizon Zero Dawn Remastered launches this October on PC and PS5
item.content:encoded:
https://www.thesixthaxis.com/2024/09/24/horizon-zero-dawn-remastered-launches-this-october-on-pc-and-ps5/

Probably one of the worst kept secrets of recent times has finally been confirmed, the original Horizon Zero Dawn is being remastered for PlayStation 5 and PC. The game will launch on 31st October 2024 and if you own the original PS4 title you can upgrade for $9.99.

As well as update the graphics so they match those found in Forbidden West over ten hours of dialogue has been re-recorded and facial animations are improved.

We scored the game a great 8/10 upon its original 2017 release, enjoying the deep sci-fi tale that Guerrilla told, the precision battling against the robots that now roam the Earth, and soaking in the technical showcase that Guerrilla had cooked up on PS4. However, we did find that Aloy was rather  lacking character,  and I would assume that it’s her dialogue and animations that have been improved.

The Horizon Zero Dawn remaster was first reported on in 2022, the initial story from MP1ST and then being backed up by VGC, claiming that an updated version of the 2017 hit would bring the title to the newer iteration of Guerrilla Games’ engine from Horizon Forbidden West, updating it with new character models, lighting, animations, and also refining things like accessibility features and add quality of life improvements to the core gameplay.

There have been numerous repots of the game since then including one just last week when Horizon Zero Dawn Remastered was rated by the ESRB, with the revitalised game set to come to both PC and PlayStation 5 according to the listing.

Horizon is also getting a LEGO game in the very near future, that looks a lot of fun, and there’s also a fantastic homage to the game in the recently released Astro Bot.

Source: YouTube

item.title: Monster Hunter Wilds is coming out in February 2025
item.content:encoded:
https://www.thesixthaxis.com/2024/09/24/monster-hunter-wilds-is-coming-out-in-february-2025/

Monster Hunter Wilds has a release date, and it’s set for 28th February 2025, the long-awaited monster hunting sequel coming to PS5, Xbox Series X|S and PC.

There were plenty of new revealed within the announcement trailer, which debuted a new main monster: the White Wraith. There were plenty of other story teasers, monsters, details on the Scarlet Forest location, and more.

With the release date confirmed, Capcom also explored pre-order options. Pre-ordering will net the Guild Knight Layered Armour and Hope Charm Talisman. A PS Store exclusive is the Digital Mini Artbook.

Then there’s the Premium Deluxe Edition, which includes the base game, 3 DLC packs and all this other stuff:

Oh, and if you played Monster Hunter World and Iceborne, then there’s bonus Palico equipment that will be waiting for you – you need to have save data from these games though.

As always, there’s plenty of new ideas being added into the mix with a new Monster Hunter game, even if the main point remains the same. Players will have access to new gadgets and companions like the Seikret, a new creature that you can mount and ride across the open world. The Seikret can also automatically follow the trail to get you to the target monster, and give you time to heal, sharpen your weapons and grab useful items and materials that you meander past. It also has a holster to let you swap between primary and secondary weapons.

Then there’s the Slinger, which is standard gear for hunters in Monster Hunter Wilds and will replace the Wirebug from Monster Hunter Rise. It can shoot out ammo gathered in the environment, and can grapple to draw in distant items (even while riding the Seikret), or interact with certain parts of the environment.

We got to go hands on with the game recently, sharing impressions in our Monster Hunter Wilds preview. Nic said, “Time will tell how Wilds eventually plays out, but I must say — I am more excited than ever to get my hands on the final game. Just like at the Meowscular Chef’s kitchen, this small taste of a gorgeous offering from Capcom has me desperately wanting more.”

item.title: Monster Hunter Wilds Gets Release Date Of February 28, 2025
item.content:encoded:
https://wccftech.com/monster-hunter-wilds-gets-release-date-of-february-28-2025/

Monster Hunter is one of Capcom's best-selling franchises, and today, during the September State of Play, Monster Hunter Wilds got its official release date trailer. The game is slated for release on February 28, 2025. If those interested in the game decide to pre-order the game, they will get exclusive bonuses for pre-ordering on PlayStation 5. This includes some cosmetics, such as a talisman, a unique armor set, and a mini digital artbook. The pre-order also comes with save data bonuses, which can be transferred over to Monster Hunter: World and Monster Hunter World: Iceborne, which can give you cosmetics for your Felynes.  At the moment, it's uncertain whether these pre-order exclusives will also be available to those on PC.

In this trailer, players got to see some of the high-definition gameplay that they can expect to dive into once the game releases, as well as some of the new monsters that players will be encountering as well as some of the story elements, all of which are showcased in a short trailer of three minutes and a half.

The trailer shows off the Scarlet Forest, one of the new regions that players will get to explore in the upcoming game. Monster hunter Wilds is one of the most highly anticipated games, with the game-winning multiple awards at Gamescom, despite the fact it is not due to release until February next year.

Monster Hunter Wilds has received multiple trailers thus far, and although they are usually a couple minutes long, it never feels long enough trying to uncover the huge world that Monster Hunter Wilds is shaping up to be.

There are three editions that people can purchase: The Standard Edition, the Deluxe Edition, and the Premium Deluxe Edition, where people will get the most cosmetics and bonuses in the Premium Deluxe Edition.

Capcom will also be confirmed to be an exhibitor at the Tokyo Game Show 2024, which takes place on 26 September, where it's confirmed that they will be showing off Monster Hunter Wilds alongside games such as Street Fighter 6, Monster Hunter Now, and Ace Attorney Investigations Collection, for example.

Whether this means that people will get more trailers for Monster Hunter Wilds will have to wait until September 26, with the event taking place at 7 AM PT / 10 AM ET / 3 PM BST.

If you want to know whether the game is worth picking up, Francesco did a preview of the game over at Gamescom.

item.title: Ghost of Yotei is the next entry in Sucker Punch’s Ghosts series
item.content:encoded:
https://www.theverge.com/2024/9/24/24253576/ghost-of-tsushima-2-yotei-ps5-pro-2025

To close out Sony’s State of Play presentation, Sucker Punch debuted a first look at the next game in its award-winning Ghosts series. Dubbed Ghost of Yotei, players will inhabit a new female protagonist named Atsu, who wields a shamisen in addition to a samurai’s traditional sword. According to the trailer description, Atsu will travel the wilds around Mount Yotei accompanied by a mysterious wolf companion.

Sucker Punch Studios, the developers behind the Sly Cooper and Infamous series, released Ghosts of Tsushima back in 2020. The game was praised for its quiet, contemplative moments as much as it’s Akira Kurosawa-style samurai action. Earlier this year, Sucker Punch released a PC port of Tsushima and confirmed that a movie based on the game is in the works, with John Wick director Chad Stahelski tapped to lead the project.

In the blog post announcing the game, Sony stated that Ghost of Yotei was Sucker Punch’s first game built specifically around the PS5. According to the developers, Ghost of Yotei will offer the same kind of beautiful observation moments as its predecessor while adding new features as well.

Image: Sony

“We have massive sightlines that let you look far across the environment, whole new skies featuring twinkling stars and auroras, even more believable movement from wind on grass and vegetation,” said Andrew Goldfarb, communications manager at Sucker Punch. “Our new setting also gives us the opportunity to introduce new mechanics, gameplay improvements, and even new weapons.”

Sony didn’t share release date details, only pegging the game to a 2025 release window.

item.title: Everything We Saw At Today's PlayStation State Of Play
item.content:encoded:
https://kotaku.com/playstation-state-of-play-ghost-of-tsushima-2-yotei-1851656575

It’s been an awkward month for PlayStation. While the company put out the delightful platformer Astro Bot that celebrates the brand’s past 30 years, it also shut down the hero shooter Concord and issued refunds in record time. There’s also been some drama around its recent announcement of the $700 PlayStation 5 Pro. But the show must go on, and so it does with today’s State of Play presentation. The 30-minute showcase put a spotlight on upcoming PlayStation 5 games. If you want to watch the full show, you can do that below. If you just want to know the highlights, read on.

Starting off the show is a brief trailer for Astro Bot, which is getting a free update with new speedrun levels and new character cameos from Helldivers and Stellar Blade, among others. The update will launch this fall.

Next up is The Midnight Walk, a clay, stop-motion-styled horror game from Moon Hood Studios, the developers who made Lost in Random. The game will come to PlayStation 5 and PSVR2.

Keeping the creepy vibes going but with a bit of a twist is Hell Is Us. The science-fiction soulslike had a moody trailer with some frightening enemies that delve into body horror.

We got a new look at Metro Awakening ahead of its November 7 PSVR2 release date. Your mileage may vary on if this is what you were looking for after the series has been dormant for five years, since 2019's Metro Exodus.

Archeage Chronicles is a fantasy action game that looks like a real tough, fast-paced challenge, but it will also include multiplayer to bring friends along on some of the fights. It’s coming to PS5 in 2025.

Well, this is awkward. Palworld, the “Pokémon with Guns” survival game, is here and coming to PlayStation today, fresh off the announcement that Nintendo is suing its developer for patent infringement. Get it while you can, I guess.

Two classic PlayStation RPGs are coming to PS5 and PS4 in spring 2025. The Lunar Remastered Collection includes both the original Lunar: The Silver Star Story Complete and Lunar: Eternal Blue Complete with updated visuals and widescreen mode.

We got a new update on Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Shredder’s Revenge. This included a brief look at the Radical Reptiles DLC, which adds new playable characters Mondo Gecko and Mona Lisa. The game is also getting a remixed soundtrack with several guest composers. Both additions are available today.

Holy shit! Keanu Reeves is voicing Shadow the Hedgehog in a post-launch update for Sonic X Shadow Generations, featuring Reeves’ version of the character from the upcoming Sonic the Hedgehog 3 movie in levels based on the film. The update will launch on December 12.

Bringing back the RPG vibe is Fantasian Neo Dimension. Producer Hironobu Sakaguchi showed a bit of the game’s turn-based battle system and put a spotlight on the soundtrack, which is composed by Final Fantasy legend Nobuo Uematsu. The game launches on December 5 on PlayStation 4 and 5.

BioWare showed off some new footage of Dragon Age: The Veilguard, spotlighting Taash, the Qunari companion who we haven’t seen much of before today, and, more notably, a boss fight with a dragon. The game launches on October 31.

Next we get a trailer for Alan Wake II’s The Lake House expansion. It’s spooky as fuck and coming in October.

Bringing us back to the “big franchise people want more of but in VR this time” trend is Hitman World of Assassination. The PSVR2 game is coming in December.

It leaked earlier today, but Legacy of Kain Soul Reaver 1-2 Remastered is bringing the classic PlayStation games to PS4 and PS5 on December 10.

While it’s not an old PlayStation game, Fear the Spotlight looks a lot like one. Blumhouse’s upcoming horror game was one of the coolest things I played at Summer Game Fest, and it’s coming to PS4 and PS5 on October 22.

Next up is Towers of Aghasba, an island-building game coming to early access in November.

Epic announced that it’s bringing a splitscreen mode to Lego Fortnite to support local play on one system. Also, there’s an ugly Fortnite DualSense controller coming, with pre-orders going live on October 3.

Koei Tecmo made an appearance with Dynasty Warriors Origins. Along with a new trailer of the upcoming Musou game, the studio confirmed it will launch on January 17.

Capcom brought a new trailer for Monster Hunter Wilds, which spotlighted a terrifying fight with a giant sea creature, a giant bear, and some silly little guys dancing. It has something for everyone. The game launches on February 28.

Horizon gets a big ol’ spotlight with both a new trailer for Lego Horizon Adventures (which for some reason doesn’t acknowledge the game is also coming to Switch), as well as the rumored Horizon Zero Dawn Remastered coming to PC and PS5. It has re-recorded mocap and brings the game up to the level of visual fidelity its sequel Forbidden West. It will launch on October 31. If you own the original PS4 version, you can upgrade to the new one for $9.99.

Stellar Blade is getting a photo mode update, which is available today. Also available today is the game’s soundtrack on all your favorite streaming services. This game sounds like it has some bangers, actually? Oh, also, Stellar Blade is getting a Nier collaboration later this year. We briefly see what looks like a 2B skin for the main character.

Next, Sony gave a few updates on games coming to PlayStation Plus. Subscribers will be able to download the Dead Space remake, Doki Doki Literature Club, and WWE 2K24. Blood Omen: Legacy of Kain and Dino Crisis from the original PlayStation will also be added to the Classic Collection later this year, and The Last of Us Part I will be joining the PlayStation Plus game catalog on Thursday, September 26 to commemorate “The Last of Us Day.”

Sony showed off a few new DualSense controllers and console covers, including an Indigo, Pearl, and Teal set. Pre-orders will go live on October 3.

Sony system architect Mark Cerny made an appearance to talk about the PlayStation 5 Pro and all its updated tech. This included a list of some (but by no means all) games that will be enhanced for the system.

  • Final Fantasy VII Rebirth
  • Horizon Forbidden West
  • The Last of Us Part II: Remastered
  • Gran Turismo 7
  • Hogwarts Legacy
  • Alan Wake II
  • Stellar Blade
  • Dragon’s Dogma II
  • Star Wars Jedi: Survivor
  • Metal Gear Solid: Snake Eater remake
  • Dragon Age: The Veilguard
  • The First Descendant
  • The Crew Motorfest
  • Resident Evil Village
  • Demon’s Souls
  • Resident Evil 4 remake
  • F1 24
  • Ratchet & Clank: Rift Apart
  • Assassin’s Creed Shadows
  • Marvel’s Spider-Man 2

Closing out the show is Ghost of Tsushima sequel Ghost of Yōtei from Sucker Punch. The sequel is slated to come to PlayStation 5 in 2025 and will feature a new protagonist, a samurai woman named Atsu.

item.title: Here's Our First Look At Ghost Of Tsushima 2, Out Next Year
item.content:encoded:
https://kotaku.com/ghost-tsushima-2-yotei-atsu-woman-trailer-release-date-1851656719

Ghost Of Tsushima 2 is confirmed and coming out sooner than you think. Sony revealed the first look at the sequel to the 2020 open world samurai game during today’s State of Play showcase. It looks excellent and it’s coming out in 2025. It’s also officially called Ghost of Yōtei and stars a woman.

Suggested Reading

Agatha All Along Star Sasheer Zamata On Witchcraft And Star Trek

  • Off
  • English

Suggested Reading

It takes place in 1603 and stars a brand new character named Atsu, who sets out on a journey with her pet wolf in the lands surrounding Mount Yōtei to bring justice, possibly get revenge, and do all the other cool, wonderous, and bloody things players might remember from the first game. It looks a lot more freeform than the original, which dealt mainly with a land under siege from a foreign invader.

Here’s the trailer:

“People come to North to disappear,” a man says at the start of the trailer. He’s later killed by a wandering female samurai who then sets out across lush valleys, dense autumn forests, and beautiful snowy fields in search of something —though we don’t quite know what. The end of the trailer teases the mysterious warrior Atsu looking out at the mountain Yōtei alongside an allied wolf while dual-wielding swords.

“This area was outside the rule of Japan, and filled with sprawling grasslands, snowy tundras, and unexpected dangers,” Sucker Punch comms manager Andrew Goldfarb wrote over on the PlayStation Blog following the announcement. “It’s a far cry from the organized samurai clans who lived in Tsushima, and it’s the setting for an original story we can’t wait to tell.”

Taking place hundreds of years after the first game, it seems like Ghost of Yōtei will be a fresh start, offering the chance for players to explore a new cast of characters, betrayals, and, most importantly, a vast new map. While some fans will no doubt be sad to leave the protagonist of Ghost of Tsushima, Jin Sakai, behind, hopefully the new slate gives this game the opportunity to make some bold choices and explore different kinds of gameplay.

It will also no doubt look amazing on the PS5 Pro, adding something for players who were initially skeptical of the expensive new hardware to look forward too.

item.title: Stellar Blade Photomode is Finally on the Way
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/stellar-blade-photomode-is-finally-on-the-way/

The team at Shift Up has revealed that the long-awaited photomode function is headed to Stellar Blade. This will be made available in a future update, allowing players to set Eve up in various poses, tweaking the environment and adding filters as they see fit. It’s a feature that many believe the game should have been released with, but it’s better late than never, right?

Don’t You Dare

The introduction of photomode in Stellar Blade will inevitably lead to more than a few lewd pictures surfacing on social media. Part of me believes that’s why Shift Up neglected to include this feature in the first place. As soon as it drops, gamers worldwide will be flocking back to Stellar Blade to don the skimpiest outfits imaginable and go wild snapping digital photos.

That’s not all that’s coming, though. The team also confirmed that a digital soundtrack is being released on streaming platforms, allowing users to bask in the battle tracks or ambient compositions that unravel as they’re exploring the semi-open-world environments of Stellar Blade.

Later this year, a Stellar Blade x Nier Automata crossover is coming, marking the arrival of the game’s first substantial expansion. It basically writes itself at this point, though.

item.title: PlayStation State of Play September 2024: Everything Announced
item.content:encoded:
https://www.ign.com/articles/playstation-state-of-play-september-2024-announcements

Sony's latest PlayStation live stream has come to an end and we've gathered all of the news and trailers from the event today. The September State of Play focused on updates about 20 PS5 and PS VR2 games and we got a closer look at how the PlayStation 5 Pro is enhancing games.

You can dive into all of the latest PlayStation news from the show below, and we will keep updating this page with the new announcements and trailers as we receive more information.

Ghost of Tsushima 2 Announced as Ghost of Yotei

Arguably the biggest announcement from the show today was that the sequel to Ghost of Tsushima will be arriving in 2025. The new game will be titled Ghost of Yotei and focus a new protagonist, Atsu. The announcement trailer gave us a pretty good look of what we can expect from the upcoming game from Sucker Punch.

Horizon Zero Dawn Remastered Announced

We got official confirmation that Horizon Zero Dawn is getting remastered for the PS5. Anyone who owns the PS4 version will be able to upgrade to the PS5 version when it comes out for $9.99. The remaster is arriving on October 31, 2024 and will include 10 hours of re-recorded dialogue as well as visual enhancements.

Monster Hunter Wilds Release Date Revealed

Monster Hunter Wilds is officially coming on February 28, 2025. The new Monster Hunter title will be arriving on PS5, Xbox Series X|S, and PC. The new trailer we've included above showed off new monsters as well.

Astro Bot DLC Announced for Fall 2024

Astro Bot arrived on PS5 earlier this month and we gave it a sparkling 9 out 10 review. The game is receiving a free DLC sometime in Fall 2025 that has five new online speedrun levels and 10 new bots to rescue.

The Midnight Walk Announced

From the creators of Lost in Random comes a claymation style game with some rather Tim Buron-esque art. We do not yet have a release window for the The Midnight Walk, but you'll be able to play it on PS VR 2 or PS5.

Hell Is Us Gets a New Gameplay Trailer

The new trailer for Hell Is Us showcased another horror game that looks a bit like a soulslike game. It includes sword combat, a drone on your shoulder, and does not yet have a release date for PlayStation.

Palworld Is Out on the PS5 Today

If you've been hoping to dive into Palworld on your PS5, now you can! Although the Pokemon-like game is currently in a legal battle with Nintendo and the Pokemon company, it has officially come to Playstation.

Metro Awakening VR Arrives on November 7

The upcoming VR game, Metro Awakening, received a new trailer and will be arriving on November 7, 2024.

Archeage Chronicles Is Releasing in 2025

We got a new trailer for Archeage Chronicles, an upcoming soulslike game with a medieval setting and big scary bosses. The land of Auroria awaits you!

Lunar Remastered Collection Announced for 2025

A remastered collection of the Lunar games has officially been anounced for Spring 2025. The collection will included updated visuals and wide-screen support.

TMNT: Shredder's Revenge Radical Reptiles DLC Is Free and Out Now

A new TMNT: Shredder's Revenge DLC was announced today and it's already out! You can currently download the new content for free, which includes a rmixed sountrack.

Legacy of Kain: Soul Reaver 1 & 2 Remastered Is Coming in December

PlayStation accidentally leaked earlier today that Legacy of Kain: Soul Reaver 1& 2 remastered will be arriving on December 10, 2024. The remaster comes with improved visuals for PS5 and PS4 and is arriving on the 25th anniversay of the original's release.

Hitman 3 VR: Reloaded Is Arriving In December

Another PS VR2 game coming down the pipeline is Hitman 3 VR: Reloaded, which will be arriving in December 2024. The game will offer full dual wield and support various hand gestures. You can track ou tthe latest trailer above.

Fantasia Neo Dimension Is Arriving on December 5

The upcoming RPG, Fantasian Neo Dimension will be arriving on PS5 on December 5. It's a tactical game from the creators of Final Fantasy.

Keanu Reeves Will Headline a Sonic x Shadow Generations DLC

Sonic the Hedgehog 3 is arriving in theaters later this year, but before that happens, his voice will be appearing in the upcoming DLC for Sonic x Shadow Generations.

LEGO Horizon Adventures Arrives on November 14

The upcoming LEGO and Horizon collaboration is coming to PS5 and PC on November 14, 2024. You can officially preorder the new game starting on October 3, and we will see if it makes our list of the best LEGO games.

Towers of Aghasba Early Access Announced

The upcoming city building game Towers of Aghasba hass been announced for early access at the September State of Play. Starting in November 2024 you will be able to start playing the game on PS5.

Fear the Spotlight Gets a New Trailer

Fear the Spotlight is a PS1-inspired horror game from Blumhouse. With a cozy aesthetic and pixelated visuals, you'll be able to enjoy this new horror title starting on October 22.

New PS5 Controller Colors Announced

Although games were the biggest highlight of the show, Sony also announced a new line of PS5 Dualsense controllers. The Chroma collection of accesories includes Chroma Pearl, Chroma Indigo, and Chroma Teal, which you'll be able to preorder starting in October. You can check out IGN's guide to the best PS5 controllers to see more like this.

Dynasty Warriors: Origins Is Arriving in January 2025

Dynasty Warriors: Origins is coming to PS5 on January 17, 2025. The new trailer that came alongside the release date reveal shows gameplay for the upcoming game as well as some combat.

More Games Confirm PS5 Pro Support

PS5 Pro architect Mark Cerny gave an update at today's State of Play about a number of games that will be offering PS5 Pro support. The list included Dragon Age: The Veilguard, Assassin's Creed Shadows, and Metal Gear Solid Delta.

PlayStation Plus Monthly Games for October 2024 Announced

In addition to the other reveals from the show, PlayStation has also unvelied the lineup of games for PlayStation Plus games in October 2024. The new additions include WWE 2K24 and Dead Space, both of which we have reviewed very favorably.

Looking for more PlayStation news and games? You can dive into our picks for the best PS5 games or see our updated database of all of the upcoming PS5 games coming in 2024 and beyond.

item.title: Dynasty Warriors: Origins launches January 17, 2025
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gematsu.com/2024/09/dynasty-warriors-origins-launches-january-17-2025
  • PC
  • PS5
  • Xbox Series

Overview trailer released.

Dynasty Warriors: Origins will launch for PlayStation 5, Xbox Series, and PC via Steam on January 17, 2025, publisher Koei Tecmo and developer Omega Force announced.

Get the latest details below.

Developed by Omega Force, Dynasty Warriors: Origins introduces a nameless hero to the 1 vs. 1,000 gameplay of Warriors lore as a mysterious martial artist steps to the forefront of the game’s epic story. The title promises to deliver the most intense combat of any game in franchise history.

As seen in the stirring new video, Dynasty Warriors: Origins begins during the dawn of an era of tremendous upheaval in the Three Kingdoms, when the original protagonist—a traveling martial artist with amnesia—finds himself in the middle of great conflict. Here, the game’s hero partakes in this dramatic tale of ancient China, where he plays an active role in the storyline while giving players first-hand experience in the drama of the war-torn land. Throughout the journey, players will make various choices as the protagonist—but he too carries a secret—which will have an impact on the Three Kingdoms, helping illustrate a turbulent time in history in exciting new ways.

Throughout his battles, the nameless hero will sometimes forge into combat on his own, while at other times, he’ll join alongside allied officers and soldiers to storm towards large forces of enemies. Players can rely on the strength of accompanying Musou officers, issue commands to units, or charge forward into oncoming armies, varying up strategies to conquer the deadly battlefield in this epic showcase of 1 vs. 1,000 action.

Throughout Dynasty Warriors: Origins, there will also be many well-known and powerful officers such as Lu Bu waiting to test the young martial artist’s skill. Battles against these officers who possess near superhuman strength results in combat that is both highly action-oriented and challenging while keeping players on the edge of their seats throughout every encounter. This extraordinary power also thrives within your allies as the Companion officer that accompanies the protagonist can become temporarily playable if certain conditions are met during battle, leading to an exhilarating experience of clearing out enemies with dominance on a completely different scale!

item.title: Meet Your New Voice Assistant: Jack Skellington, The Amazon Echo Dot
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/meet-your-new-voice-assistant-jack-skellington-the-amazon-echo-dot/1100-6526658/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Halloween is almost upon us, and if you're looking to get into the festive swing of things, you can bring some nightmarish decor to your home with this Jack Skellington Echo Dot variant. Available starting October 8, these bundles are inspired by The Nightmare Before Christmas and feature the grinning and ghoulish face of Jack Skellington. Listed for $90, these are currently priced at $63 as part of a limited-time offer ahead of Amazon Prime Big Deal Days. If you already own a 4th- or 5th-Gen Echo Dot, you can buy the shell separately for $40. Jack Skellington can become your new voice assistant starting October 8.

Amazon has three bundles available--Glacier White, Deep Blue Sea, and Charcoal--in case you'd like a splash of color after Halloween and you decide to remove the Skellington shell. Inside, you'll find a 5th-Gen Echo Dot and the Jack Skellington shell.

Amazon Echo Dot Jack Skellington bundles

  • Glacier White -- $63 ($90)
  • Deep Blue Sea -- $63 ($90)
  • Charcoal -- $63 ($90)

Echo Dot smart speakers offer a range of handy features. You can play music, audiobooks, and podcasts from Amazon Music and other platforms, sync your phone up to it via Bluetooth, and use Amazon's Alexa voice assistant. The Dot also works with other types of smart home devices from both Amazon and other brands, and you can program it to control compatible devices with your voice. Essentially, the Echo Dot can be a smart home hub, and this limited-edition model is also a fitting decoration as we head into the holiday season.

item.title: Horizon Zero Dawn's remaster arrives in October and it'll cost $10 to upgrade
item.content:encoded:
https://www.eurogamer.net/horizon-zero-dawns-remaster-arrives-in-october-and-itll-cost-10-to-upgrade

Launching on both PS5 and PC.

It wasn't much of a secret given it'd already been rated by the ESRB, but Sony's Horizon Zero Dawn remaster is finally official, and it'll be launching for PS5 and PC on 31st October this year.

Horizon Zero Dawn Remastered (which was first rumoured all the way back in 2022) is the work of series developer Guerrilla Games and the Sony owned Nixxes, and promises a range of enhancements for the now seven-year-old original.

As per Sony's latest State of Play broadcast, it'll include "more than ten hours" of rerecorded conversation motion capture, as well as "countless" graphical improvements said to give the remaster the same visual fidelity of Horizon Forbidden West. These include upgraded character models, improved shaders and textures, enhanced conversation cameras to go with the new mo-cap, plus support for 3D audio, DualSense haptic triggers, and even your old saves.

Accessibility wise, Horizon Zero Dawn Remastered supports many of the features introduced in Horizon Forbidden West, including remappable controls, haptic cues, and assist toggles.

Sony is also touting native support for its upcoming PlayStation 5 Pro, although it gets bit vague on the specific enhancements your £700 will get you, promsing "improved" graphical features and "ultra-high fidelity at blazing fast framerates".

As for the PC version, it'll include the PlayStation overlay with Trophy support, as well as a range of PC-exclusive features. Expect support for ultra-wide resolutions, NVIDIA DLSS 3, and AMD FSR 3.1, with more details due to be shared at a later date.

And if that grabs you, Horizon Zero Dawn Remastered - which includes all content seen in the Complete Edition - will cost $49.99 USD on the PlayStation Store, Steam, and Epic. Plus, there's some good news on the upgrade front, with Sony confirming existing owners of Horizon Zero Dawn or Horizon Zero Dawn Complete Edition (including those that acquired the game through PlayStation's Play At Home initiative) can upgrade to the new PS5 or PC version for $9.99.

item.title: Hitman World of Assassination is coming to PSVR 2 in December
item.content:encoded:
https://www.thesixthaxis.com/2024/09/24/hitman-world-of-assassination-is-coming-to-psvr-2-in-december/

The revamped Hitman World of Assassination is coming to PSVR 2 in December, IO Interactive has revealed, bringing dual wielding and plenty more VR-native tweaks to console VR.

This will be available as a paid $9.99 / €9.99 / £8.99 upgrade for existing owners of Hitman World of Assassination on PS5.

The PSVR 2 version of Hitman World of Assassination will include dual-wielding, full ambidexterity, and room-scale play, as well as generally improved controls and gameplay mechanics, when compared to the original PSVR release. New interactions mean that you’ll have active reloading, on-body weapon holstering, sniper scope aiming, and manual motions to take on disguises.

It seems that this is a distinct and separate endeavour to the Meta Quest 3 version, Hitman 3 VR Reloaded, which launched back in June. That was developed by XR Games in collaboration with IO Interactive, but XR Games gets no mention here. Additionally, it looks like this aims to retain more of the original game art style, as opposed to the standalone VR centric makeover.

Of course, this isn’t the first time that Hitman has come to VR as Hitman 3 feature a VR mode for PlayStation VR and, a few months after release, for PC VR. That was created by a small team within IO Interactive, and featured its own set of VR accommodations, such as reworking the cover system and using free-form movement for melee instead of scripted animations.

Hitman 3 first launched back in early 2021, a concluding chapter to the ambitious trilogy that IO Interactive had started five years previous. In our Hitman 3 review, Jim said, “Charting the series’ progress since that 2016 Paris debut has been a fascinating journey. IO have learned a lot over the past five years and that really shows in Hitman 3. It’s a flashier, more fluid evolution of IO’s original template – a rewarding conclusion to one of the most unique video game franchises around, and one we’ll continue playing for many weeks and months to come.”

Source: Press release

item.title: Palworld is out today on PS5
item.content:encoded:
https://www.thesixthaxis.com/2024/09/24/palworld-is-out-today-on-ps5/

Pocketpair has announced that Palworld is coming to PlayStation 5… today! The hit ‘Pokémon with guns’ game is ditching Xbox console exclusivity on this latest step through early access.

Palworld launched into early access on PC and Xbox at the start of this year – likely just out of convenience that Xbox offers with for developers going through early access – and took the world by storm. Yes, there’s Pokémon-like creatures and there are guns, but it leans into other genres like survival and base building that appealed to a lot of people.

The game has just been in the headlines as Nintendo and The Pokémon Company announced a lawsuit against the indie developer, seemingly for ingfringing a recently acquired patent for capturing and summoning monsters in battle.

Pocketpair’s response to the lawsuit said, “We have received notice of this lawsuit and will begin the appropriate legal proceedings and investigations into the claims of patent infringement.

“At this moment, we are unaware of the specific patents we are accused of infringing upon, and we have not been notified of such details.

“Pocketpair is a small indie game company based in Tokyo. Our goal as a company has always been to create fun games. We will continue to pursue this goal because we know that our games bring joy to millions of gamers around the world. Palworld was a surprise success this year, both for gamers and for us. We were blown away by the amazing response to the game and have been working hard to make it even better for our fans. We will continue improving Palworld and strive to create a game that our fans can be proud of.”

We’ll have a long road ahead to see how that lawsuit pans out, but Pocketpair isn’t going to change its development goals in the short term. Launching on PlayStation is going to bring a huge new audience to the game.

item.title: Metro Awakening VR heads to PSVR 2 this November
item.content:encoded:
https://www.thesixthaxis.com/2024/09/24/metro-awakening-vr-heads-to-psvr-2-this-november/

The highly anticipated next title in the Metro series, Metro Awakening VR, will launch on PlayStation VR2 on November 7th. The date was revealed along with a new trailer in this evening’s State of Play broadcast.

The brand new reveal trailer showed us a good portion of what you can expect, and in line with the franchise’s previous entries, it looks like a healthy dose of creeping through deadly tunnels and abandoned underground stations, while blasting a series of mutants, monsters and unfriendly human beings with an array of weaponry. It seems that the protagonist will also suffer from the same sort of mental hallucinations that were found in the first game in the series.

Based on the Metro 2033 book, the videogames have been with us for many years, forging their first-person shooter roots on the Xbox 360 and PS3. Titles in the series include Metro 2033, Metro Last Light, and most recently Metro Exodus which met with rave reviews at launch, including our own rave review which said, “Metro Exodus provides an immersive FPS experience that marks a new milestone for the franchise. Its survival-horror, sandbox and shooter elements are remarkably well balanced, constituting an engaging and thrilling game that’ll leave you no stranger to a good jump scare. The once linear horror franchise has been reformed, introducing expansive environments to indulge in without derailing the narrative. Metro Exodus is a must play.”

The game is being handled by VR experts Vertigogames, whose previous works include the Arizona Sunshine series, After the Fall and The 7th Guest VR, all of which means that we’re excited to see what they can do with the evocative setting and narrative of the Metro series. It seems like a perfect fit, and with the power of PSVR2 it has the potential to be a visual delight when it hits our eyes sometime in the future.

item.title: Palworld Trailer Still Gets Showcased During State of Play
item.content:encoded:
https://wccftech.com/palworld-trailer-still-gets-showcased-during-state-of-play/

Pocketpair and Nintendo are currently tackling a lawsuit, with Nintendo suing them over patent infringement. While it wasn't confirmed, it was suspected by many that the reason Pocketpair pulled out of Tokyo Game Show as an exhibitor was due to the lawsuit. Despite this, a brand-new trailer for Palworld was shown today during the PlayStation State of Play. As confirmed after the trailer, Palworld is officially available on PlayStation 5 today so that people can dive into the world of pocket monsters with guns.

At the moment, it's uncertain what this will mean for those who decide to purchase the game and whether it will eventually be taken down and refunded to those who purchase it. It will remain to be seen until the lawsuit has wrapped up after being issued in Tokyo. However, lawsuits are a lengthy process, and one where a company has to come up against Nintendo means that it will most likely drag on as Nintendo is not only powerful but vicious in making sure that there are no sorts of mods, emulators, or even fan-games that are remotely close to Nintendo's own products.

Despite the lawsuit, Palworld has continued to do extremely well for itself, being one of the most popular games that has been released this year. After the lawsuit was issued, Palworld continued to rise on the charts. According to an IP expert who spoke to GamesRadar+, it's likely that the lawsuit will take five years to settle, despite the possibility that the lawsuit could very easily be wrapped up in one. However, it's said that Pocketpair is more than capable of affording seeing this lawsuit through to the end.

Although many have made commentary on the lawsuit, even Pocketpair themselves are unsure as to why the lawsuit has taken place, as Nintendo has never expressed any issue with their game up until this point. The Pal designs are evidently not the issue, as the game has been out for a while, and Nintendo instead decided on working to take down the mods that added actual Pokemon into the game. This lawsuit revolves around patents, of which Pocketpair is completely unsure as to what patents they could have infringed.

However, with the game now being released on PlayStation 5, it could spell good things for Pocketpair, and at the very least, will line their pockets further with money to be able to continue through the lawsuit and try and come out victorious.

item.title: Legacy of Kain: Soul Reaver 1 and 2 are getting a remaster
item.content:encoded:
https://www.theverge.com/2024/9/24/24253265/legacy-of-kain-soul-reaver-1-and-2-remastered-ps5-state-of-play-aspyr-media

Legacy of Kain: Soul Reaver is one of those series of games that has always felt unjustly left behind to me, and at Sony’s State of Play today, it’s finally getting its due, at least a little. The two classic Crystal Dynamics games, which I enjoyed in their penultimate form on the Dreamcast, are getting a remaster for PlayStation consoles, courtesy of Aspyr Media. The remasters come out on December 10th.

The two Soul Reaver games were supernatural action puzzlers with a heavy Lovecraftian bent released first for the original PlayStation and Windows PCs in 1999, then for the Sega Dreamcast in 2000. In them, you play Raziel, a jawless vampire who was brought back to life by an elder god. He’s equipped with an ethereal sword (the titular Soul Reaver) that engulfs his arm when it’s time to fight.

The games played a little like a Legend of Zelda game and involved puzzle solving, jumping between the physical world and a “spectral realm,” and hack-and-slash fighting. You gain new abilities by defeating other vampires as you progress.

The remaster looks a lot like other Aspyr glow-ups, with enhanced character models and redone textures and effects, but otherwise, they look mostly unchanged. Here’s hoping the game doesn’t suffer the fate of some of the buggier Aspyr remasters (looking at you, Star Wars: KOTOR II and Star Wars: Battlefront Classic Collection), because I’ve been waiting to play Soul Reaver again for many, many years.

item.title: Palworld Out Now On PS5 Days After The 'Pokémon With Guns' Survival Game Gets Sued By Nintendo
item.content:encoded:
https://kotaku.com/palworld-pokemon-nintendo-lawsuit-ps5-sony-1851656704

Who’s ready to capture some Pokémon-looking creatures and force them into labor camps to manufacture assault rifles? As announced in the new State of Play, PlayStation 5 players can now join in the Palworld fun with a port out on Sony’s platform just a week after maker Pocketpair was sued by Nintendo for alleged patent infringement.

  • Off
  • English

The survival crafting sim exploded in popularity on PC via Steam and Xbox Series X/S via Game Pass at the start of 2024 despite only being in Early Access. Players fight whimsical creatures and capture them to help build bases and take on tougher monsters with multiplayer raids reminiscent of what you might find in an MMO.

While the millions of concurrent players it had at launch have since moved on, Palworld continues to be a force to be reckoned with in the multiplayer live-service space, such that Nintendo decided to finally sue the Pokémon-inspired game eight months later, citing patent infringement.

“Nintendo will continue to take necessary actions against any infringement of its intellectual property rights including the Nintendo brand itself, to protect the intellectual properties it has worked hard to establish over the years,” the company wrote in a statement at the time. “At this moment, we are unaware of the specific patents we are accused of infringing upon, and we have not been notified of such details,” responded Pocketpair in its own statement. “It is truly unfortunate that we will be forced to allocate significant time to matters unrelated to game development due to this lawsuit.”

Experts have weighed in on the dispute, suggesting that Nintendo wouldn’t bring a lawsuit against the indie developer unless it felt it had a very strong case. They cited a very specific and highly technical patent around throwing a spherical object to capture a creature that could be one of the things at issue in the lawsuit, though Nintendo hasn’t yet said what exact parts of Palworld infringe on its IP. It’s still unclear what impact that lawsuit could have on the game or its existence on rival platforms.
